Award.AwardTitle: III-Nitride LED Structures on Sidewall Grown Semipolar Facets
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description: This research project focuses on the development and understanding of a new approach for fabrication of semipolar III-nitride structures for light emitting diode (LED) applications. The method is based on stripe patterning of c-plane GaN templates and deep-groove etching, followed by sidewall re-growth to form semipolar facets on which InGaN/GaN quantum wells are grown. The dominant lateral growth modes are expected to result in a significantly reduced dislocation density. The LEDs based on the semipolar materials should benefit from a reduced polarization-induced field and enhanced indium incorporation, and are regarded as a promising solution of the "green gap" problem in the nitride LED technology. By employing a variety of structural and optical characterization, the research team studies the preferential faceting formation and dislocation reduction for different patterning methods as well as the growth kinetics for different semipolar facets; the indium and doping-element incorporation efficiency in different directions in lateral growth regimes; the strain and internal quantum efficiency in structures with different semipolar alignments.

Non-technical Description: The knowledge gained from this research project can be of significant importance for establishing a design of low defect-density, cost-efficient InGaN/GaN quantum-well structures with semipolar alignment, and for guiding technological development of light emitting diodes with improved internal quantum efficiency in blue-green region. The research activities leverage the PIs' previously established national and international collaborations. The project provides training of graduate students by exposing them to comprehensive, application-motivated academic research through curriculum development, guest lectures and seminars. The project intends to involve and support women and underrepresented minorities, as well as high-school students conducting summer science research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objectives of this research are: to evaluate the effect of different surface orientations and growth strategies; to understand the dominating growth mechanisms, defect formation and evolution in epitaxial layers with different orientations, aiming to establish the best approach for producing low-defect-density material with semipolar facets; to study the incorporation and diffusion process of doping elements taking places in vertical and lateral growth modes in nitride growth on semipolar facets with different orientations in order to gain thorough knowledge about the internal quantum efficiency and polarization properties of the emission in structures intended to operate in green spectral region; and to develop efficient and reliable method for polarity determination of nitride layers and low-dimensional structures.

The outcome of the project concerning intellectual merit include: understanding of the broadband structural and optical properties of pristine versus doped materials in growth along different crystallographic directions. We have studied LED device structures along different crystallographic directions on bulk GaN substrates, as well as sidewall and mass-transport growth, employing etched grooves via masks with different periodicity, crystallographic alignment and groove depth allowed formation of semipolar faceting in scalable way over large area wafers.

We have developed a nondestructive approach to determine the wurtzite GaN crystal polarity based on X-ray photoelectron diffraction. The nondestructive method for polarity identification, developed initially for polar wurtzite crystals, was further developed and implemented for various semipolar orientation and for nanostructures, including for low-dimensional structures, such as quantum dots embedded in polar and semipolar heterostructures. By using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy we were also able to determine the surface electron band bending of polar GaN crystals with opposite polarities. The method was generalized for crystals with large band bending, where the core level energies change noticeably with the emission angle.

We have examined several methods for passivating the surface of polar, nonpolar and semipolar GaN with different chemistries, including simple physisorption, in-situ functionalization using phosphonic acids, and a two-step carboxylic acid attachment with a peroxide pretreatment. Our results confirm binding at the organic-inorganic interface through the presence of amine/amide species on the surface and verifying a probable path for influencing specific functionalities for technologies spanning fields of energy, biomedical science, and chemical sensing.

Broader impact of this project includes training graduate students in nitride materials synthesis and characterization, developing skills in preparing publications and presentations of results at conferences. The results from the project were broadly disseminated via book chapters, journal and proceedings publications. The International Collaboration between the NCSU and the Institute of Physics at Czech Academy of Science has been exercised via several exchanged visits, including students visits. Various joint measurements were performed, mostly focused on surface studies of nitride structures with various semipolar faceting, surface orientations and functionalization. In addition to learning about new characterization methods, the students had a chance to be part of international team, to communicate with scientists, to attend social and cultural events.
